posts.title: UK will roll out chemical castration for sex offenders
top_comments: How do they decide who qualifies for this? That part seems vague. Is it based on how many times someone offends, or the type of offense? And who decides that, a judge or some review panel?
The UK really does not have a great history with this policy
And then the definition of "Sex Offender" changes.
Just like they did to Alan Turing.
Glad they also figured out how to know with 100% certainty 100% of the time who is guilty. Otherwise this would be barbaric.
Yikes.  I was under the impression that chemical castration did not change recidivism rates at all.
When prisons overflow, policy shifts fast. But mandatory chemical castration opens doors we might not be ready to walk through.

I would encourage anyone who supports this to think about how loosely people can define “sex offenders”. Because it will not be long until that definition expands beyond just rapists. 

Seeing the current trends in the UK, I could completely see a future where conservatives include trans people presenting as their chosen gender or porn stars or homosexual people in that definition. The government should have no control over something like this, the potential for abuse is fucking enormous.
This is what drove Allen Turing to suicide

There are many, MANY issues with this. Off the top of my head:

1. Sex crimes cases are often based off he-said-she-said. Which usually results in no convictions at all, unfortunately for the victims, but it also means that the convictions that DO happen CAN have no DNA evidence or solid scientific proof of guilt. Which is to say, there's a less than 100% chance that everyone convicted of a sex crime has actually committed a sex crime.
2. Chemical castration is not generally designed to be permanent but rather sustained by regular exposure. But complications happen, permanent damage occurs, and lives can be ruined. When there's a less than 100% chance that every convicted sex criminal is in fact a criminal, a less than 100% reversal rate for the consequent punishment is insane.
3. Chemical castration doesn't stop sex crimes. In fact, in many studies it's been proven to have the opposite effect. You know what's worse than a violent rapist/child rapist who committed these crimes in the first place? A sexually frustrated one with no outlet except more extreme violence.

I for one LOVE the idea of child molesters and rapists losing their junk (though I like a more physical, un-anesthetized removal concept), but that doesn't change the fact that it's pure revenge fantasy and doesn't actually SOLVE a thing. This is a mistake.

ETA: While everyone is also completely correct to be concerned about the precedent, these things are almost never implemented on anything but a 'volunteer' basis. As in, the criminal has to opt-in to be chemically castrated vs staying in prison. It's meant to partially be proof of repentance and the desire to reform. It's shady and a bad call over all, but it's still the UK - they're PROBABLY (🤞) not going to at any point in the modern day consider FORCING chemical castration on sex criminals.

top_comments:

Their tornado button is broken. This story feels surreal.
A city with 60 sirens and not one sounded. That’s not just a mistake, that’s systemic failure.
This is so bizarre. I lived in a small town close to St Louis, and I swear they tested the tornado sirens once a week.

I live close to an area that has an emergency siren like this, but I’m not too familiar as I am new to this area. Does anyone know if you can connect your phones to the sirens so when they go off your phone gets an alert? Is this a thing?

*Sarah Russell, commissioner of the City Emergency Management Agency in St. Louis, will remain on paid administrative leave as an external investigation proceeds into what went wrong.*  


*Until a permanent replacement for Russell is found, St. Louis fire captain John Walk will serve as the interim emergency management commissioner.*



I’ll be interested to see the conclusions of the external investigation. I wonder what they’ll determine.

There are too many inconsistencies here.  On reading down through this thread, it appears that people in the STL area are saying that they were testing the alarms in the days leading up to the storm. So they were working.

The story from officials is that the person in charge of pushing 'the button' was away and that there was a failure to communicate that 'the button' needed to be activated. So there is only one way, means and location to activate the system?

When they went to push 'the button', the same one that they had been testing with a few days earlier, it was broken?

This seems to be a systemwide breakdown in planning, chain of command, and procedures.  You don't install 60 sirens around the city without acknowledging the threat of a tornado in your area is a very real possibility.  You don't spend that type of money without putting some type of infrastructure in place, including maintenance, testing, redundancy and personnel to make sure that it works.  There has been some systemwide failure here.
We blow ours on the first Wednesday of every month at noon whether we want to or not

posts.title: UK will roll out chemical castration for sex offenders
top_comments: How do they decide who qualifies for this? That part seems vague. Is it based on how many times someone offends, or the type of offense? And who decides that, a judge or some review panel?
The UK really does not have a great history with this policy
And then the definition of "Sex Offender" changes.
Just like they did to Alan Turing.
Glad they also figured out how to know with 100% certainty 100% of the time who is guilty. Otherwise this would be barbaric.
Yikes.  I was under the impression that chemical castration did not change recidivism rates at all.
When prisons overflow, policy shifts fast. But mandatory chemical castration opens doors we might not be ready to walk through.

I would encourage anyone who supports this to think about how loosely people can define “sex offenders”. Because it will not be long until that definition expands beyond just rapists. 

Seeing the current trends in the UK, I could completely see a future where conservatives include trans people presenting as their chosen gender or porn stars or homosexual people in that definition. The government should have no control over something like this, the potential for abuse is fucking enormous.
This is what drove Allen Turing to suicide

There are many, MANY issues with this. Off the top of my head:

1. Sex crimes cases are often based off he-said-she-said. Which usually results in no convictions at all, unfortunately for the victims, but it also means that the convictions that DO happen CAN have no DNA evidence or solid scientific proof of guilt. Which is to say, there's a less than 100% chance that everyone convicted of a sex crime has actually committed a sex crime.
2. Chemical castration is not generally designed to be permanent but rather sustained by regular exposure. But complications happen, permanent damage occurs, and lives can be ruined. When there's a less than 100% chance that every convicted sex criminal is in fact a criminal, a less than 100% reversal rate for the consequent punishment is insane.
3. Chemical castration doesn't stop sex crimes. In fact, in many studies it's been proven to have the opposite effect. You know what's worse than a violent rapist/child rapist who committed these crimes in the first place? A sexually frustrated one with no outlet except more extreme violence.

I for one LOVE the idea of child molesters and rapists losing their junk (though I like a more physical, un-anesthetized removal concept), but that doesn't change the fact that it's pure revenge fantasy and doesn't actually SOLVE a thing. This is a mistake.

ETA: While everyone is also completely correct to be concerned about the precedent, these things are almost never implemented on anything but a 'volunteer' basis. As in, the criminal has to opt-in to be chemically castrated vs staying in prison. It's meant to partially be proof of repentance and the desire to reform. It's shady and a bad call over all, but it's still the UK - they're PROBABLY (🤞) not going to at any point in the modern day consider FORCING chemical castration on sex criminals.
